Her shift ended at 3 AM, but the city never slept. She stormed out of the precinct, badge slapping against her chest like a goddamn reminder of another wasted night. Another dead-end chase, another dealer laughing in holding, another damn kid shot up with bad gear.

She'd been doing this for over a decade, but tonight it tasted bitter. Like ash on her tongue. Every fucking shift was the same - running towards chaos while life passed her by. She was 37, single, and goddammit, she deserved more than this.

Her phone buzzed with another message from her mom - "When are you gonna settle down, honey? Your sister's kid is already talking." Bitterness surged like bile in her throat. She wasn't fucking ready to be an auntie, let alone a mother. Not when she was still chasing ghosts on these godforsaken streets.

She unlocked her car door, the familiar scent of old coffee and cold metal hitting her. Her radio crackled to life, "Officer Harris, we've got another one..." She slammed her fist against the steering wheel, "Fuck!" This was her life now? A never-ending stream of fucking chaos?

She drove towards the scene, lights flashing, sirens wailing. But tonight, even that wasn't enough to drown out the bitter taste in her mouth.

Instead, she stood up, walked to the window, and looked out at the empty campus. The rain began to fall, tapping against the glass like nature's own Morse code, sending messages only it understood. His hands trembled as he tried to mix the colors she loved so much - that damnable shade of cerulean blue, the one she'd said reminded her of his eyes. But today, even the pigment seemed uncooperative, refusing to blend into anything but a muddy mess.

"I can't do this," he muttered through gritted teeth, throwing the palette onto the floor with a clatter. It was supposed to be their anniversary today. Two years since they'd first met at that godforsaken art gallery. Two years since he'd decided her smile was worth painting forever. Two years since everything changed.

His eyes fell upon the photograph propped up on the mantelpiece - them laughing together, her head resting on his shoulder, his arm around her waist. Her eyes shone brighter than any paint he could mix. He felt a surge of anger rise within him, hot and bitter. "Why did you leave me?" he shouted at the photo, his voice echoing in the empty room.

He picked up the photograph, intending to hurl it across the room, but his fingers lingered over her face. Instead, he crumpled to the floor, tears streaming down his cheeks. He clutched the photo to his chest, his sobs shaking him like a storm-tossed ship. "I miss you so much," he whispered into the silence, his voice barely audible.

As the sun began to set outside, casting long shadows across the room, he realized he hadn't painted anything all day. Not even a single line. But perhaps that was okay. Perhaps today wasn't about creating art; it was about acknowledging pain. And maybe, just maybe, tomorrow would be different.
